text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with mushroom and ricotta
bruschetta that's right this recipe is
so simple it's complex which are my
favorite kind and by the way if you know
some foodies and want to really annoy
them simply pronounce this for coda in
mushroom bruschetta mandu they hate that
but it is pronounced bruschetta and this
actually is not a true bruschetta in
that we're not going to grill it over
fire but it is delicious nonetheless and
here's how you do it so let's start by
making our cheese mixture I have some
whole milk ricotta I'm gonna grate on
some lemon zest about 1 lemons worth
very finely grated don't get the white
stuff that's bitter
we just want those beautiful lemon oils
some red pepper flakes some freshly
ground black pepper a big pinch of salt
in one whole egg alright we're going to
mix that together till completely smooth
and by the way when you see a recipe
that calls for a beaten egg ask yourself
do I really need to beat this egg before
I put it into something I'm going to mix
anyway probably not so sometimes people
who write recipes want you to wash extra
dishes do not fall for it ok and once we
mix that up we can just set that aside
until needed and then it's on to the
next one on to the next one which is
going to be the bread base of our
bruschetta and as I said earlier we're
not going to grill this over charcoal
we're just going to throw it in a
toaster and lightly toast it it's just
barely toasted because this is going to
go in a very hot oven alright so I want
you to lightly toast for thick slices of
bread while it's still warm I want you
to douse it with olive oil generously
that's going to add richness flavor and
help insulate it and then we're going to
go ahead and divide our ricotta cheese
mixture on top of the four brush Jettas
and I only said bruschetta because I've
been saying bruschetta and the same
people that were annoyed by you calling
it bruschetta will be just as annoyed
I'm mispronouncing to you but you know
what those people have a problem I don't
even know why we're talking about them
but anyway we're gonna divide the cheese
mixture amongst the four slices of bread
pop that in a very well preheated 425
degree oven for about 12 to maybe 15
minutes until the cheese is just set and
the edges of the bread are getting nice
and crusty and golden brown and those
beauties are ready to top with our
mushroom mixture which I haven't showed
you how to make yet alright so we're
going to take some mushrooms I'm going
to trim a little bit of the bottom of
the stem off even though there's
no reason to do that and I'm going to
slice them up thickly you know the drill
pick a thickness and go with it but
you're going to want to try to get them
about the same so they cook evenly and
all kind of look the same when they're
done and of course if you're making this
for real at home and just don't watch
these videos like some kind of disturbed
voyeur you're going to want to make the
mushroom mixture and have it ready for
when your cheese and bread come out of
the oven okay anyway we're going to
slice our mushrooms up we're going to
throw those in a big giant skillet with
some olive oil and butter on medium-high
heat
I'm going to give it a big pinch of salt
and here's what's going to happen
first they're going to get wet then
they're going to get dry then they're
going to get wet again and then they're
going to end up damp okay and that's not
nearly as confusing as it sounds because
when you saute this many mushrooms in a
pan a lot of water comes out and it
takes a while for that to evaporate but
if you keep sauteing and keep stirring
and again we're on like medium-high heat
eventually the water evaporates as you
well know butter and oil don't evaporate
so once the liquid is gone the mushrooms
will start sauteing and five or six
minutes later I had some beautifully
browned mushrooms at that point I'm
going to throw in a little bit of onion
product it could be garlic it could be
leeks it could be shallots it could be
plain onion here I have a handful of
spring onions also known as scallions or
green onions and you can just toss these
in and saute em but I like to make a
little opening in the middle to start to
saute non the bare metal plus if
someone's watching it looks totally like
you know what you're doing your friend
to be like hey did you see that thing
she did in the middle of the pan with
the onions that was tight
but anyway dump those in sautee them for
about two or three minutes and then as
warned we're going to make this wet
again so I'm going to add a splash of
Marsala wine you could use white wine
you could use sherry but I do like a
little splash of alcohol in this and in
my mouth while I'm cooking so I'm going
to put in a splash of that we're going
to say cook until evaporate it but
that's only going to take a couple
seconds because those mushrooms are
going to absorb that like instantly so
I'm just going to cook those for like a
minute then I'm going to dump in a nice
splash of chicken stock a little squeeze
of fresh lemon I also decided to give it
a few grinds of black pepper I'm going
to turn the heat down to medium-low and
we're simply going to braise that until
almost all the liquids gone alright I
just want them damp I don't want them
dry I don't want them wet
I want them damp just like that
right last in final steps you can turn
your heat down to low you're gonna throw
in some fresh herb and a big chunk of
butter I'm using parsley but you can use
any sweeter like tarragon chervil basil
even but anyway once the butter is
melted you're going to check for final
seasoning you're going to spoon that
over that crusty bread and that
beautiful awesome baked ricotta cheese
maybe we'll throw in a little more lemon
zest maybe a little more parsley it's up
to you you either Grand Poobah a final
presentation and that is done ricotta
and mushroom bruschetta such a delicious
and versatile recipe this could be an
amazing breakfast with a poached egg or
fried egg on top
serve it with a nice little green salad
and you've got a perfect lunch you could
even throw a piece of grilled meat next
to this and use it as a dinner entree
side dish but no matter what you use it
for it is so tasty such a great
combination of textures and taste that
crunchy bread that creamy cheese with
that little hint of lemon in there and
then of course what's not good with
sauteed mushrooms over it almost nothing
so even though the components are very
simple and rustic and basic the final
product seems complex and sophisticated
so I really do hope you give this a try
head over to food wishes comm for all
the ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
